\#\#\# User: Problem on a Mac Mini Mid 2011\. I have looked through other articles and couldn't get help. Any help?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Add the grub arguments `noapic noacpi nosplash` in place of `quiet splash`. `noapic` and `noacpi` are kernel boot options. ACPI stands for Advanced Configuration and Power Interface and APIC stands for Advanced Programmable Interrupt Controller.

Immediately after the motherboard / computer manufacturer logo splash screen appears when the computer is booting, with BIOS, quickly press and hold the `Shift` key, which will bring up a GNU GRUB menu screen. With UEFI press (perhaps several times) the `Esc` key to get to the GNU GRUB menu screen. Sometimes the manufacturer's splash screen is a part of the Windows bootloader, so when you power up the machine it goes straight to the GNU GRUB menu screen, and then pressing `Shift` is unnecessary.

You will see a GNU GRUB menu screen that looks like this:

[![GNU GRUB menu screen](https://i.stack.imgur.com/GCPLl.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/GCPLl.png)

Press `e` to enter editing mode. This will bring up a GNU GRUB screen that looks like this:

[![GNU GRUB screen](https://i.stack.imgur.com/SoYht.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/SoYht.png)

Use the arrow keys to navigate when screen editing the above screen. Navigate to after the string on this screen that starts with `root=`. In this example screen the full string is `root=` followed by `UUID=` and a hexadecimal string as shown below:

```
root=UUID=bcf15ef2-a0b2-4753-9558-8399dd12a729   

```

Immediately after this string replace `quiet splash` by `noapic noacpi nosplash`. This change is only temporary — it will just be used once and GRUB won't remember it in the future. It may be possible to make these changes permanent by changing the ACPI and APIC settings in the Mac Mini's UEFI firmware. Press `Ctrl`\+`X` or `F10` to boot with the kernel boot options that were added. If you make a mistake, press `Esc` to go back to the previous screen.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are trying to troubleshoot a booting issue on a Mac Mini Mid 2011. Which of the following sets of kernel boot options would you add to the GRUB menu to potentially resolve ACPI and APIC-related problems?

A) quiet splash
B) noapic noacpi nosplash
C) apic acpi splash
D) nogrub noefi noboot

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B) noapic noacpi nosplash. These kernel boot options are specifically mentioned in the documentation as potential solutions for hardware-related issues, especially on older Mac models. 

"noapic" disables the Advanced Programmable Interrupt Controller, "noacpi" disables the Advanced Configuration and Power Interface, and "nosplash" prevents the splash screen from displaying during boot. These options can help bypass potential conflicts with the Mac's hardware that might be preventing successful boot.

Option A is incorrect as it represents the default options that are typically replaced when troubleshooting.
Option C is incorrect as it uses "apic" and "acpi" which would enable these features rather than disable them.
Option D is incorrect as these are not valid kernel boot options and would likely cause more boot problems rather than solve them.

To apply these options, one would need to access the GRUB menu by pressing Shift (for BIOS) or Esc (for UEFI) during boot, then edit the boot entry by replacing "quiet splash" with "noapic noacpi nosplash".

displays a code block and asks

> Code blows on MailApp line with message "invalid email: Range". I don't understand the error message. Please help.

To which I responded with:

> The error is saying that your var Addr \= dataRange.getCell(1, 11\); call is getting a result of a Range, so when you pass that to the sendEmail function it says Invalid email and shows the value to be Range.
> 
> 
> You can confirm this by console.log(Addr); before the call.
> 
> 
> The question asked for the meaning of the error message, I believe @Barmar has provided the cause in his comment that you are referencing the title of the column instead of the current row due to using '1' instead of 'i'.

Yet one low\-quality\-posts reviewer wrote

> This does not provide an answer to the question. To critique or request clarification from an author, leave a comment below their post.

I'm struggling to understand how that review is valid, the question is answered, I edited my post when further information was provided by @Barmar to keep it as complete as I could and gave him credit for it, I would delete mine if he came back and added his own answer, but now someone else will write the same thing.

Can anyone give me some insight into why my post was deleted so I can avoid the unpleasant way I am feeling in future?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I believe that the reviewers who voted to delete acted in error here. What you posted *was* an answer to the question.

I'm not sure what misled them. Perhaps the bottom paragraph, where you reference a comment? Not only is that paragraph unclear, I frequently see this mislead reviewers, who think that an answer is an attempt to *reply* to a comment, when it is really an attempt to promote a comment to a proper answer (with the appropriate attribution).

At any rate, I've undeleted your answer. It qualifies as an answer by our standards, and it was inappropriate for it to have been deleted.

At the same time, I've also closed the question, because it is one of those situations where the answer is unlikely to be helpful to anyone else in the future, and thus does not need to stick around. It was clearly not a quality question in the first place, and in the future, you might consider whether your time could be better spent crafting an answer for other questions.

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In a pharmaceutical quality control report, which of the following statements is most precise and unambiguous regarding regulatory compliance of residual host cell protein levels?

A) The level of residual host cell protein in all drug samples complies with the regulatory requirements.

B) The levels of residual host cell protein in all drug samples comply with the regulatory requirements.

C) The level of residual host cell protein in each drug sample complies with the regulatory requirements.

D) The average level of residual host cell protein across all drug samples complies with the regulatory requirements.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
A) This option is ambiguous. The singular "level" combined with plural "samples" could be misinterpreted as referring to an average or overall level, rather than individual compliance.

B) While this improves on option A by using plural "levels," it still doesn't clearly specify that each individual sample complies.

C) This is the most precise and unambiguous statement. It clearly indicates that every single drug sample individually meets the regulatory requirements for residual host cell protein levels.

D) This option explicitly refers to an average, which could mask individual samples exceeding limits, and thus does not ensure regulatory compliance for each sample.

The key is to ensure clarity that each individual sample meets the requirements, which option C does best.

\#\#\# User: Suppose $P\_1$ and $P\_2$ are the orthogonal projections onto the closed subspaces $M\_1$ and $M\_2$ of a Hilbert space $X$.

If $M\_2 \\subseteq M\_1$, is it always the case that $P\_2P\_1 \= P\_2$?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes. For any $x\\in X$, $$P\_1P\_2x\=P\_2x,$$ since $P\_2x\\in M\_1$. Since orthogonal projections are selfadjoint, 
$$
P\_2\=P\_2^\*\=(P\_1P\_2\)^\*\=P\_2P\_1\. 
$$

3.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Let X be a Hilbert space with closed subspaces M₁ and M₂, where M₂ ⊆ M₁. Let P₁ and P₂ be the orthogonal projections onto M₁ and M₂ respectively. Which of the following statements is true?

A) P₁P₂ = P₂P₁ = P₂
B) P₁P₂ = P₂, but P₂P₁ ≠ P₂
C) P₂P₁ = P₂, but P₁P₂ ≠ P₂
D) Neither P₁P₂ nor P₂P₁ is equal to P₂

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: 
The statement A is correct for the following reasons:

1. P₁P₂ = P₂: This is true because M₂ ⊆ M₁. For any x ∈ X, P₂x ∈ M₂ ⊆ M₁, so P₁(P₂x) = P₂x.

2. P₂P₁ = P₂: This is proven in the documentation. Since orthogonal projections are self-adjoint, P₂ = P₂* = (P₁P₂)* = P₂P₁.

3. Combining these results, we get P₁P₂ = P₂P₁ = P₂.

B is incorrect because it states P₂P₁ ≠ P₂, which is false.
C is incorrect because it states P₁P₂ ≠ P₂, which is false.
D is incorrect because both P₁P₂ and P₂P₁ are equal to P₂.

This question tests understanding of orthogonal projections, nested subspaces, and the properties of adjoint operators in Hilbert spaces.

\#\#\# User: You **may** also send a resume to this email address.

What does this "may" mean?

Why isnt it can?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Two generations ago teachers insisted that only *may* should be used in asking or granting permission to do something, and that *can* signifies only ability to do something. Jolenealaska indicates that this was still common in the late 70s. 

This in fact represented literary practice in the 19th century, and a primary object of schoolteachers has always been to encourage use of prestige forms—what used to be called ‘proper English’—and to stamp out non\-standard forms.

Since the middle of the 19th century, however, *may* has been giving way to *can* in permissions, and it is my impression that schoolteachers have pretty much given up that particular fight. Nonetheless, the 'rule' still prevails in formal, written English†; and there are lots of people out there (many in very senior positions) who I adhere to the rule.

I consequently recommend that you observe this distinction in any formal writing you undertake if you have any hope of becoming a Recognized Authority (at which point, of course, you may write anything you please). Failure to do so may result in bad marks while you are still a student, and afterwards may annoy any superiors of my age or Jolenealaska's—at least until we are all retired or dead.

---

† The written dialect is always quite conservative, for a couple of reasons: 

* Very few people grow up in households where the written dialect is spoken, so it is essentially a foreign language which can only be mastered through reading. Consequently, during the years you are learning the dialect you are working entirely with texts older than you are yourself, or written by authors who are older; and by the time you master the language, and start publishing your own texts you are yourself older than many or most of your readers.
* It is not only a much richer language lexically, it is a much more complex one syntactically, because it must express more complex ideas with more precision and writers have no opportunity to interrupt their discourses to explain what readers have not understood. It has many more 'rules' to ensure that what you say is what you mean and cannot be understood to mean something else. It is consequently averse to innovation, because innovation means changing the rules, and changing the rules means changing the meaning of the existing texts which **are** the language.

\#\#\# User: First I zeroed out the entire USB flash drive:

```
dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/sdb

```

And then I used [`fdisk(8)`](http://linux.die.net/man/8/fdisk) to create a type `c` W95 FAT32 (LBA) partition on it and formatted the partition as FAT32:

```
mkfs -t vfat /dev/sdb1

```

And then I used Ubuntu Startup Disk Creator to make it a bootable Ubuntu USB stick (the .iso file is verified and not at fault). However, whenever I use the drive to boot I get a `Boot error` message. What's going wrong? How to fix this?
Edit: No other distributions (Fedora, Debian, etc.) on other bootable USB disk creators (UnetBootin, etc.) work. The tool runs on Ubuntu 15\.10; the file used is of Ubuntu 15\.10\.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Ubuntu Startup Disk Creator is sometimes buggy. Use `dd` command instead.

```
sudo umount /dev/sdb1
sudo dd if=/path/to/ubuntu.iso of=/dev/sdb bs=4M; sync

```

Wait for it to write to the device. That's it. Here `bs` refers to `Byte Size`

\#\#\# User: So I was wondering if the correct phrase for asking a question is "what does it does/do?" Then it struck me that it feels odd to say "what does it does". Then I did some Googling and apparently the correct phrase is "what does it do?"

But my question is why does it uses 'do' at the end of the question? I mean, the subject in question is an 'it', so shouldn't it use 'does' instead of 'do'? Can't we use 'does' to end a question? or am I missing something?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: To make questions in English, we invert word order, and this is easily when we are already using a verb that inverts easily, most likely a modal verb, *to be*, or *to have*.

> He **will** visit... \-\> When **will** he visit?
> 
> 
> He **is** angry because... \-\> Why **is** he angry?

But most verbs don't readily invert, and as such we use the auxiliary form of *to do* to make questions (or negations).

> He **runs** because... \-\> Why **does** he **run**?
> 
> 
> It **does**... \-\> What **does** it **do**?

The only verb(s) that get conjugated within a clause are the first, or the ones that tie directly to the subject and not another verb.

> He **does** not want to eat it.
> 
> 
> *Not:* He **does** not **wants** to **eats** it.\*
> 
> 
> He **is** eating and **will** go to sleep soon.
> 
> 
> *Not:* He **is** eating and **will** **goes** to sleep soon.\*

This is the same case for questions. The auxiliary verb "to do" is tied to the subject in typical questions and as such is the conjugated verb, the verb that would normally be tied to the subject is tied then to "to do".

> **Does** he want to go the store with me? (As a statement: "He **does** want to go to the store with me.)
> 
> 
> *Not:* **Does** he **wants** to go to the store with me?\* (As a statement: "He **does** **wants** to go to the store with me.\*)
> 
> 
> But my question is why **does** it uses 'do' at the end of the question?
> 
> 
> *Not:* But my question is why **does** it **uses** 'do' at the end of the question?\*

And, as such:

> What **does** it do?
> 
> 
> *Not:* What **does** it **does**?

11.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Which of the following sentences correctly uses the auxiliary verb "to do" in forming a question?

A) What does the machine does to process the data?
B) Why does he wants to leave early today?
C) How often does she practice the piano?
D) When does they arrive at the airport?

Correct Answer: C

Explanations:

A) Incorrect. This sentence incorrectly conjugates both "does" and the main verb "do". The correct form should be "What does the machine do to process the data?"

B) Incorrect. This sentence incorrectly conjugates the main verb "want". The correct form should be "Why does he want to leave early today?"

C) Correct. This sentence properly uses the auxiliary "does" with the subject "she" and leaves the main verb "practice" in its base form.

D) Incorrect. This sentence uses "does" with a plural subject "they", which is incorrect. The proper form would be "When do they arrive at the airport?"

This question tests understanding of auxiliary verb usage in question formation, subject-verb agreement, and proper verb conjugation in English.

```
\section{Fee Ra Huri / Omnia}
\begin{music}
\instrumentnumber{1}            % number of instruments
\setstaffs1{1}              % number of lines per instrument
\generalmeter{\allabreve}   % time stamp. meterC is 4/4, allabreve is 2/2 or cut time.
\generalsignature{2}            % sets the key. a number greater than 0 is sharp, smaller than 0 is flat
\startextract
% bar 1
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{mi} \slur iiu2 \cu e \en % mi
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{si} \qlp i  \en % si
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{si} \cl i \en % si
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{si} \cl i \en % si
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{la} \slur igd{1.5} \qu h \en % la
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{sol} \qu g \en % sol
\bar % bar 2
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{la} \qu h \en % la
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{sol} \uptext{\it tr}  \qu g \en % sol
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{mi} \qu e \en % mi
\bar % bar 3
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{re} \qu d \en % re
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{sol} \qu g \en % sol
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{sol} \qu g \en % sol
\bar % bar 4
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{fa} \qu f \en % fa
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{mi} \qu e \en % mi
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{fa} \ibu1f2 \qu f \en % fa
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{sol} \qu g \en % sol
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{la} \qu h \en % la
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{si} \tbu1\qu i \en % si
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{la} \qu h \en % la
  \Notes \zcn{-7}{mi} \qu e \en % mi    
\endextract
\end{music}
\end{document}

```

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Your real problem is that you do not connect the notes to the beam. When I delete the unwanted spaces, I get the first image, which shows that your notes have the normal stems, and the beam starts nicely (accidentally) at the top of the first note's stem, but then slope 2 is not enough for covering the others.
The right code to connect the notes is:

```
\ibu1f2\qb1f\zcn{-7}{sol}\qb1g\zcn{-7}{la}\qb1h\zcn{-7}{si}\tbu1\qb1i

```

[![image 1, disconnected stems](https://i.stack.imgur.com/VyGtz.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/VyGtz.png)
[![image 2, connected stems](https://i.stack.imgur.com/MRr5m.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/MRr5m.png)

The second image shows that the last stem is a little bit shorter than the first.
Other problems in your examples are:
Your text is placed arbitrarily due to the spaces inserted. As you can see in my images, the syllable always starts on the left of the note. If you want it centered, you could use \\ccn (paragraph 17\.3 of the musixdoc manual), but it does not align nicely, much more effective (if you do not want to invoke musixlyr) is `\zsong{*text*}` or `\csong{*text*}`, without the need of indicating a hight (see paragraph 23\.1\). The advantage is that musixtex then uses the notes as measure for the horizontal distances. Text is always tricky in music, at least when you do not tell musixtex how long your text is. I used the various forms in the first measure of the third example.
[![image 3, text placing](https://i.stack.imgur.com/SPvHJ.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/SPvHJ.png)

Another problem is your use of the slurs. The first starts too early. If you want to have it started at the stem of the note, use `\ibsluru0e` and end it before the third (or the second, in case you wanted 1 distance length instead of your manually adjusted 2 lengths) note with `\tslur0c` (the c is the correction to avoid closing at stem hight, see paragraph 10\.2 of the manual).
With this code:

```
    \documentclass{article}
% packages
\usepackage{background}
\usepackage{musixtex}
\usepackage{tikz}
\thispagestyle{empty}
\begin{document}
\section{Fee Ra Huri / Omnia}
\begin{music}
\instrumentnumber{1}            % number of instruments
\setstaffs1{1}              % number of lines per instrument
\generalmeter{\allabreve}   % time stamp. meterC is 4/4, allabreve is 2/2 or cut time.
\generalsignature{2}            % sets the key. a number greater than 0 is sharp, smaller than 0 is flat
\startextract
% bar 1
\Notes\csong{mi}\ibsluru0e\cu e\cchar{-7}{si}\qlp i\tslur0c\ccn{-7}{si}\cl i\ccn{-7}{si}\cl i\ccn{-7}{la}\slur hgd{1}\qu h\cchar{-7}{sol}\qu g\en % sol
\bar % bar 2
  \Notes\zcn{-7}{la}\qu h\zcn{-7}{sol}\uptext{\it tr}\qu g\zcn{-7}{mi}\qu e\en % mi
\bar % bar 3
  \Notes\zcn{-7}{re}\qu d\zcn{-7}{sol}\qu g\zcn{-7}{sol}\qu g\en % sol
\bar % bar 4
  \Notes\zcn{-7}{fa}\qu f\zcn{-7}{mi}\qu e\zcn{-7}{fa}\ibu1f2\qb1f\zcn{-7}{sol}\qb1g\zcn{-7}{la}\qb1h\zcn{-7}{si}\tbu1\qb1i\zcn{-7}{la}\qu h\zcn{-7}{mi}\qu e\en % mi    
\endextract
\end{music}
\end{document}

```

I get the last example.
[![image 4, slurs](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ekpDx.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ekpDx.png)

Conclusion: musixtex offers a lot of commands to type music nicely, but never use spaces for horizontal alignment, and, please, study the manual well!

Here's a multi-form question based on the MusixTeX documentation:

Question: When using MusixTeX to create beamed notes, which of the following statements is correct regarding the proper method to connect notes to a beam?

A) Use \ibu1f2 before each note in the beam group, and \tbu1 after the last note.

B) Place \qb1 before each note letter in the beam group, with \ibu1f2 at the start and \tbu1 at the end.

C) Use \zcn{-7} before each note in the beam group to ensure proper connection.

D) Simply place the notes close together in the code without any special commands.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct method to connect notes to a beam in MusixTeX is to use \qb1 before each note letter in the beam group, with \ibu1f2 at the start of the group and \tbu1 at the end. This ensures that the stems are properly connected to the beam and that the beam is correctly positioned. Option A is incorrect because \ibu1f2 should only be used once at the start. Option C is incorrect because \zcn{-7} is used for text placement, not beam connection. Option D is incorrect because special commands are required to create proper beams in MusixTeX.

\#\#\# User: I am working in data science and I have to deal with the following problem for which I would like to find a simplification:

We call a function almost positive if $f(x\_1,y\_1\)f(x\_2,y\_2\)\-f(x\_1,y\_2\)f(x\_2,y\_1\) \\ge 0$ for all $0\< x\_1\\le x\_2 \< \\infty$ and $0 \< y\_1\\le y\_2 \< \\infty.$

**I would like to know:** Are there any sufficient and necessary criteria for a function $f$ to be almost positive? 

**Background:** The problem is that I often have a positive smooth function $f$ which I need to check for almost positivity. Those functions $f$ are usually cumbersome expressions such that checking 

$f(x\_1,y\_1\)f(x\_2,y\_2\)\-f(x\_1,y\_2\)f(x\_2,y\_1\) \\ge 0$
is almost impossible analytically, because one has to compare infinitely many variables which each other and unless one can simplify the expression in a clever way, checking this condition is hopeless. 

I am therefore asking whether there is an equivalent criterion to the almost positivity condition which I can check in a more direct way? Ideally there would exist an "intrinsic" criterion for functions $f$ which implies this property.

If there is nothing equivalent to almost positivity, perhaps there exist rather general sufficient conditions which imply almost positivity? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You say your function is smooth, so letting $x\_1 \= x, y\_1 \= y, x\_2 \= x \+ \\Delta x, y\_2 \= y\+\\Delta y,$ we get in the limit as the deltas go to zero, if we ignore the second order terms, then 

$$ \\dfrac{\\partial f}{\\partial x} \\dfrac{\\partial f} {\\partial x} d x d y \< 0\.$$ This indicates that we cannot ignore the second order terms, and when the smoke clears, we seem to get 

$$f\\dfrac{\\partial^2 f}{\\partial x \\partial y} \- \\dfrac{\\partial f}{\\partial x} \\dfrac{\\partial f} {\\partial x} \\geq 0,$$ which is nonlinear and hyperbolic. Changing it to an equation may or may not be enlightening.

13.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Consider a smooth function f(x,y) defined for x > 0 and y > 0. Which of the following conditions is necessary and sufficient for f to be almost positive, as defined by f(x₁,y₁)f(x₂,y₂) - f(x₁,y₂)f(x₂,y₁) ≥ 0 for all 0 < x₁ ≤ x₂ < ∞ and 0 < y₁ ≤ y₂ < ∞?

A) f(∂²f/∂x∂y) - (∂f/∂x)(∂f/∂y) ≥ 0

B) f(∂²f/∂x∂y) + (∂f/∂x)(∂f/∂y) ≥ 0

C) f(∂²f/∂x∂y) - (∂f/∂x)(∂f/∂x) ≥ 0

D) f(∂²f/∂x∂y) + (∂f/∂x)(∂f/∂x) ≥ 0

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C: f(∂²f/∂x∂y) - (∂f/∂x)(∂f/∂x) ≥ 0. This condition is derived from the limit analysis of the almost positivity definition as the differences in x and y approach zero. It captures the essential relationship between the function, its mixed partial derivative, and its partial derivative with respect to x. 

Option A is incorrect because it uses ∂f/∂y instead of ∂f/∂x in the second term. Option B is incorrect due to the plus sign instead of minus and the use of ∂f/∂y. Option D is incorrect because of the plus sign instead of minus.

This question tests understanding of partial derivatives, limit analysis, and the mathematical conditions for almost positivity in smooth functions.

\#\#\# User: My grandson's homework.... There are 23 fish. Guppies (G) are 3 more than Z\-fish (Z). There are 2 times the Z\-fish as Goldfish (GF). How many of each? .... I can see there are 8 Z\-fish (Z), 11 Guppies (G) \& 4 Goldfish (GF).... HOWEVER, When I try to prove the equation it's wrong.. Z \+ (Z\+3\) \+(Z/2\) \= 23\... equation? So Z \+ (Z/2\) \= 20/2 (\=10\).... not correct..so.. answer should be 12 (if Z\=8, G \=11, GF\=4 ). help? I don't know what I'm doing wrong. I can do a simple one if two unknowns but can't do this 3 unknowns with the fraction.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: HINT:

Let $\\arccos x\=\\theta\\implies 0\\le \\theta\\le\\pi$ and as the [Principal value](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_trigonometric_functions#Principal_values) of $\\cos$ lies in $\\in\[0,\\pi]$

So, the problem becomes $$\\tan3\\theta\=\\frac{11}2$$ and as $$\\tan3\\theta\=\\frac{3t\-t^3}{1\-3t^2}$$

$$\\implies 2t^3\-33t^2\-6t\+11\=0\\ \\ \\ \\ (1\)$$ where $\\displaystyle t\=\\tan\\theta$

Solve $(1\)$ for $\\displaystyle t$

If $\\displaystyle t\=\\tan\\theta\\ge0, \\theta\=\\arccos x$ will lie in $\\in\[0,\\frac\\pi2]$

If $\\displaystyle t\=\\tan\\theta\<0, \\theta\=\\arccos x$ will lie in $\\in(\\frac\\pi2,\\pi)$

14.answer:
Question: A complex trigonometric equation is given by tan(3θ) = 11/2, where θ = arccos(x) and 0 ≤ θ ≤ π. After substitution and simplification, this leads to the cubic equation 2t³ - 33t² - 6t + 11 = 0, where t = tan(θ). If one of the roots of this cubic equation is approximately 2.8973, what is the corresponding value of x (rounded to 4 decimal places)?

A) 0.3265
B) -0.3265
C) 0.9455
D) -0.9455

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: 
1) First, we confirm that t ≈ 2.8973 is indeed a root of the cubic equation.
2) Since t is positive, θ lies in [0, π/2].
3) We can find θ using arctan(2.8973) ≈ 1.2388 radians.
4) Since θ = arccos(x), we have x = cos(1.2388) ≈ 0.3265.

Option B is incorrect as it's the negative of the correct answer.
Options C and D are incorrect as they correspond to the case where θ would be in (π/2, π), which isn't true for the given positive root of t.

\#\#\# User: I'm little bit confused. Help me please to make everything clear. I want to buy oscilloscope and found two models suitable for me.

1. Rigol DS1102E
2. Rigol DS1102CA

But I don't understand the difference between them. I read that DS1102E has 1 GSa/s sampling rate and DS1102CA has 2 GSa/s. OK. But what does it give in practice? Both oscilloscopes have a bandwidth of 100MHz, so I won't find a difference in picture of signals on screen. Am I right? So could you explain me what is the meaning of 'sampling rate' and 'bandwidth' for modern oscilloscopes? And what is the difference between these things?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The same bandwidth means they'll both have the same attenuation for signals. It basically means that 100MHz is the [cutoff frequency](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutoff_frequency) for both scopes.

The samples per second is the resolution of the scope. If you zoom in on a signal the non\-interpolated data points will be 0\.5 ns apart for the 2GSa/s scope and 1 ns apart for the 1GSa/s. The rule of thumb ere is you can fairly accurately measure a 100MHz signal with the 1GSa/s scope and a 200MHz signal with the 2GSa/s (\~10 samples/Hz)

Obviously the more samples then the better representation of your original signal. You'll just have to weigh that with the cost difference.

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An engineer is comparing two oscilloscopes, both with a bandwidth of 100MHz, but with different sampling rates: one at 1 GSa/s and another at 2 GSa/s. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the capabilities of these oscilloscopes?

A) The oscilloscope with 2 GSa/s will be able to measure signals up to 200MHz accurately, while the 1 GSa/s model is limited to 100MHz signals.

B) Both oscilloscopes will produce identical waveforms for all signals up to 100MHz, with no visible differences.

C) The 2 GSa/s oscilloscope will provide higher resolution when zooming in on a signal, with non-interpolated data points 0.5 ns apart, compared to 1 ns apart for the 1 GSa/s model.

D) The bandwidth difference between the two oscilloscopes means that the 2 GSa/s model can capture signals twice as fast as the 1 GSa/s model.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. While both oscilloscopes have the same bandwidth (100MHz), which determines the highest frequency they can measure without significant attenuation, the sampling rate affects the resolution and detail of the captured waveform. The 2 GSa/s oscilloscope will provide higher resolution when zooming in, with non-interpolated data points 0.5 ns apart, compared to 1 ns apart for the 1 GSa/s model. This allows for a more detailed representation of the signal.

Option A is incorrect because the bandwidth, not the sampling rate, determines the highest frequency that can be accurately measured. Both oscilloscopes have the same 100MHz bandwidth.

Option B is incorrect because while the overall shape of the waveforms may be similar, the higher sampling rate of the 2 GSa/s model will provide more detail and potentially reveal high-frequency components that the 1 GSa/s model might miss.

Option D is incorrect because it confuses bandwidth with sampling rate. The bandwidth is the same for both oscilloscopes, and the sampling rate difference does not directly translate to capturing signals "twice as fast."

\#\#\# User: I have a website which uses REST Api for communication. All data retrieval and save happen through Rest Api calls(polyglot environment). Now I am planning to create an Android and iOS app . 

I have this plan of using the app and web page as the presentation layer only and all other operations(data related) to be API driven.

My question is, Is it a suggested practice to use Rest Apis for Android and iOS applications ? By doing so, will I face any complications when I have to scale up ? 

I am aware it is possible to do, but would like to know if it is the right way to do it.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Absolutely! There are only two caveats. 

1. User's have an expectation that Android and iOS apps will have much better performance than their web counterpart.
2. The app must be prepared to work when when the network connection is spotty or non\-existent.

This means the app should have as much data as possible pre\-loaded in the app package so that startup time is as short as possible. Also, it's best if the app is able to keep a local store of changes the user makes that it can upload in a background thread so the user isn't constantly subjected to a "please wait" spinner.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: When developing mobile applications (Android and iOS) that utilize REST APIs for data operations, which of the following is NOT a recommended practice for ensuring optimal user experience?

A) Pre-loading as much data as possible in the app package to reduce startup time
B) Implementing a local store to cache user changes for background synchronization
C) Relying solely on real-time API calls for all data operations without any local caching
D) Designing the app to function when network connectivity is poor or unavailable

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option A is correct because pre-loading data can significantly improve app startup time and initial user experience.
Option B is recommended as it allows the app to function smoothly even when connectivity is inconsistent, by storing changes locally and syncing later.
Option C is incorrect and not recommended, as it can lead to poor performance and usability issues when network conditions are not ideal.
Option D is a good practice, as mobile apps should be designed to work in various network conditions, including when offline.

The correct answer is C because it goes against the recommendations provided in the documentation. Relying solely on real-time API calls without local caching can result in poor performance and user experience, especially when network conditions are not optimal. The documentation emphasizes the importance of performance and offline functionality for mobile apps, which option C fails to address.

\#\#\# User: I have about 30 iPod touch devices that connect to a charger with multiple ports on it.

There are 4x 5V/2\.4A ports and 4x 5V/1A ports on the device that charges them.

It seems as though the the 5V/1A devices never get charged but I read that the for the Apple cube chargers that come with the devices they are actually the correct ones.

These devices are used until their power is drained and then returned to the charger as evidenced by how many of them I pick up on the charger read `please enter pin number after restart`.

The 5V/2\.4A charger seems to charge them faster, but the 5V/1A appears to be the correctly rated ones.

The voltage (a.k.a. electrical pressure) going into the devices is the same on both port types, but the amperage (a.k.a. the amount of electricity in the circuit) is much greater on the 5V/2\.4A ports;

As I understand electricity, it's a bit like plumbing where too much water will cause a pipe to burst, and in electrical systems, too much electricity (amps) will cause a wire to catch on fire, they are sort of analogous. 

I also know that if a battery is fully charged, you really shouldn't leave a device plugged in, it's bad for the life span of the battery.

So my question is:

* Is it dangerous to be using a charger that uses more than the recommend amperage, or can you get away with a little bit more?
* How can I ensure that these devices are taken off the charger when they are full?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 1. Excess amperage cannot "force" its way into a device (that's the danger of excess voltage). A device will only receive what it draws.
2. That is an interesting question with a more nuanced answer:

'Smart' USB chargers, like those found on Amazon, determine the amperage they provide based on the draw trends of the plugged\-in device; as long as the device is drawing, they will provide. However, some can detect and identify the sharp drop\-off of draw that accompanies the end of the charging cycle and cut power from the port.

You can find more info about this kind of thing from this answer: [https://electronics.stackexchange.com/questions/121366/how\-do\-usb\-charging\-and\-smart\-charging\-ports\-e\-g\-ankers\-poweriq\-work](https://electronics.stackexchange.com/questions/121366/how-do-usb-charging-and-smart-charging-ports-e-g-ankers-poweriq-work)

19.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An IT manager is responsible for charging 30 iPod touch devices using a multi-port charger. The charger has 4x 5V/2.4A ports and 4x 5V/1A ports. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the charging process and safety?

A) The 5V/2.4A ports are dangerous to use as they will force excess current into the devices, potentially damaging them.

B) The 5V/1A ports are ideal for charging, but devices should be manually removed once fully charged to prevent battery degradation.

C) Smart USB chargers can detect when a device is fully charged and automatically cut power to that port, making them the safest option for long-term charging.

D) The voltage difference between the 5V/2.4A and 5V/1A ports will cause the devices to charge at different rates, potentially damaging some devices.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. Smart USB chargers can indeed detect when a device is fully charged by monitoring the drop in current draw at the end of the charging cycle. They can then automatically cut power to that specific port, making them the safest option for long-term charging without manual intervention.

Answer A is incorrect because excess amperage cannot be forced into a device. The device only draws what it needs.

Answer B is partially correct about the 5V/1A ports being suitable, but modern charging systems don't necessarily require manual removal to prevent battery degradation.

Answer D is incorrect because the voltage is the same (5V) for both port types. The amperage difference doesn't cause damage, as devices only draw what they need.

A) It's used as a conjunction to introduce a temporal clause.
B) It's used as an adverb to indicate similarity in manner or degree.
C) It's used as a preposition to show the role or function of something.

The sentence implies that while school food still needs to be healthy, it doesn't need to meet the same high level of healthiness as required by the previous administration. Options A, C, and D are incorrect because "as" is not functioning as a conjunction, preposition, or pronoun in this sentence. The use of "as" here is crucial to understanding the change in policy and the contrast between the two administrations' approaches to school nutrition.

\#\#\# User: In C program I'm doing below stuff

```
int x  = 4;

```

Let us assume integer has 2 bytes in this case.
So my question here is
the variable **x** will hold two bytes that mean 16 bits. So here how the value **4** will be stored in 16 bits ?

Till now my understanding is the value 4 will be converted to Hex so it results \[0x0004] and this hex value is stored in the 16 bit boxes ?

I dont know whether my understanding is correct but I need how the value of the **x** is mapped to 16 bit boxes ? 
It would be good if anyone provide structural/graphical representation about storing values in memory.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you've got a 16bit OS then there'll be 2 bytes next to each other in memory. One with 00000100 in and the other with 00000000\. Whether it's stored as 00000000\-00000100 or 00000100\-00000000 depends on whether your OS is little\-endian or big\-endian. 
See: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endianness>

23.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a 16-bit system, an integer variable x is assigned the value 4. Which of the following correctly represents how this value is stored in memory, assuming a little-endian architecture?

A) 00000100 00000000
B) 00000000 00000100
C) 00000100 00000100
D) 11111011 11111111

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
In a 16-bit system, an integer typically occupies 2 bytes or 16 bits of memory. The decimal value 4 in binary is represented as 00000100. In a little-endian system, the least significant byte is stored at the lowest memory address. Therefore, the correct representation would be 00000000 00000100, where the least significant byte (00000100) is stored first, followed by the most significant byte (00000000).

Option A is incorrect because it represents big-endian storage.
Option C is incorrect as it duplicates the value in both bytes.
Option D is incorrect as it represents the two's complement of -4, not 4.

This question tests understanding of binary representation, endianness, and memory storage in low-level systems programming.

\#\#\# User: We agree that energy is higher in liquids than solids and is higher in gases than liquids. How can we fit this into $E\=mc^2$. As an example; 1 kg of ice has less energy than 1 L of water, right? But masses are the same specially in the case of water with density of 1,000 kg/m³. Could you please help me out with this paradox?!
All answers are appreciated.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: When one gram of ice becomes one gram of water, it gains 80 cal of energy, sometimes called *latent heat*. 80 cal is 335 J. Einstein tells us that $$m\=\\frac{E}{c^2}$$ so the increase in the mass of the sample is $3\.7 \\times 10^{\-12}$ grams.

Hardly measurable.

24.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A 100g sample of ice at 0°C is fully melted into liquid water at 0°C. Given that the latent heat of fusion for water is 335 J/g, calculate the increase in mass of the sample due to the absorbed energy. Use E = mc² for your calculations, where c is the speed of light (3 × 10⁸ m/s).

A) 3.72 × 10⁻¹⁰ g
B) 3.72 × 10⁻⁹ g
C) 3.72 × 10⁻¹¹ g
D) 3.72 × 10⁻⁸ g

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
To solve this problem, we need to:
1. Calculate the total energy absorbed by the ice during melting.
2. Use Einstein's equation E = mc² to find the corresponding increase in mass.

Step 1: Calculate the energy absorbed
Energy = mass × latent heat of fusion
E = 100g × 335 J/g = 33,500 J

Step 2: Calculate the increase in mass
Using E = mc², we can rearrange to m = E/c²
m = 33,500 J / (3 × 10⁸ m/s)²
m = 33,500 / (9 × 10¹⁶) kg
m = 3.72 × 10⁻¹³ kg = 3.72 × 10⁻¹⁰ g

Therefore, the correct answer is B) 3.72 × 10⁻⁹ g.

This question tests the student's understanding of latent heat, Einstein's mass-energy equivalence, and their ability to perform calculations involving very small quantities and scientific notation.

\#\#\# User: I'm doing some homework for a computer science class. It's been so long since I've done math, I have a question that assumes math knowledge that confuses me.

Given:
*Whether a diophantine polynomial in a single variable has integer roots.*

With the given question I need to determine if that question is solvable using computers. I know how to do that, but I don't the math required to answer this question.

So I understand "Whether a .... polynomial in a single variable has integer ...?"

My question:

* What does diophantine mean
* What is an integer root
* How do you determine if a diophantine polynomial in a single variable has integer roots?

The math behind this question is assumed to be known, once I know the answers to those three questions (really just the last one) I can answer my homework.

Note: it may or may not be obvious that this is computable, since I don't know enough about the math to say, I will say a lot of things that seem computable are not unless their input and output are acceptable to a finite precision.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There are various definitions of Diophantine equation, not all equivalent. But one standard definition goes as follows. Let $P(x\_1,x\_2,\\dots,x\_k)$ be a polynomial with *integer* coefficients. A *solution* of the Diophantine equation $P(x\_1,x\_2,\\dots,x\_k)\=0$ is a $k$\-tuple $(x\_1,x\_2,\\dots,x\_k)$ of *integers* that satisfies the equation. An equation is Diophantine partly because of its shape, but much more because of the *kinds* of solutions we are looking for.

General Diophantine equations can be exceedingly difficult. However, in principle one variable equation are simple. We have a polynomial $P(x)$ with integer coefficients. Let 
$$P(x)\=a\_0x^n\+a\_1x^{n\-1}\+a\_2x^{n\-2}\+\\cdots \+a\_n.$$
Without loss of generality we may assume that the constant term $a\_n$ is not equal to $0$. It is straightforward to show that any integer solution of the equation $P(x)\=0$ must divide the constant term $a\_n$.

So there is a simple (in principle!) algorithm for finding all the integer solutions of $P(x)\=0$: 

(i) Find all the divisors (positive and negative) of the constant term and then 

(ii) Find out, by substitution, which ones of these divisors "work."

As you know, factorization of large numbers can be computationally difficult. However, there certainly is an algorithm for factoring.

**Remark:** There is a very famous related problem, called *Hilbert's 10th Problem*. Hilbert asked for a general algorithm that would, for any polynomial $P$ with integer coefficients, and possibly many variables, determine whether the equation $P\=0$ has integer solutions. After earlier progress by a number of people, Matijasevich showed that there is *no* general algorithm of the type that Hilbert asked for. But as we noted in our answer to your question, there certainly *is* an algorithm that works for polynomials in one variable.

Diophantus himself in his *Arithmetica* looked mainly for *rational* solutions. Often, a problem is called Diophantine if we are interested in solutions that are somehow fairly closely related to the integers. 

Note that (at least to people in Logic) the famous Fermat equation $x^n\+y^n\=z^n$ is not a Diophantine equation, since the exponents are also variable. Such equations are sometimes called *exponential Diophantine*, or, more casually, Diophantine. 

**A simple example:** Consider the equation $3x^4\-12x^3\-x^2\+4x\=0$. We want to find all integer solutions of this equation. First rewrite our equation as 
$x(3x^3\-12x^2\-x\+4\)\=0$. This has the obvious solution $x\=0$. Any other solutions must be solutions of the equation 
$$3x^3\-12x^2\-x\+4\=0\.$$
By the result mentioned in the main post, any integer solution of this equation must divide the constant term $4$. The divisors of $4$ are $\\pm 1$, $\\pm 2$, and $\\pm 4$. Substitute these values in turn for $x$. We find that $x\=4$ is a root, but none of the others are. So we have found all the integer solutions of our original equation: they are $x\=0$ and $x\=4$.

25.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding Diophantine polynomials and their integer roots?

A) All Diophantine polynomials in multiple variables have a general algorithm to determine if they have integer solutions.

B) For a Diophantine polynomial P(x) = a₀xⁿ + a₁xⁿ⁻¹ + ... + aₙ in a single variable, any integer solution must be a factor of a₀.

C) Hilbert's 10th Problem, which asks for a general algorithm to determine if any Diophantine equation has integer solutions, has been proven to have a solution.

D) To find all integer roots of a single-variable Diophantine polynomial, one must check all factors of the constant term and verify which ones satisfy the equation.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Option A is incorrect because Hilbert's 10th Problem proved that no such general algorithm exists for multiple variables. Option B is wrong because integer solutions must divide the constant term aₙ, not the leading coefficient a₀. Option C is false; Matijasevich showed that no such general algorithm exists. Option D is correct and describes the process for finding integer roots of a single-variable Diophantine polynomial as explained in the given text.

\#\#\# User: I've a file with input as:

```
abc
def
ghi
23
54
12
tuy
12
iuy
56
67

```

I want to add all numbers after a character line and print it in front of character, like below:

```
abc
def
ghi 89
tuy 12
iuy 123

```

Can anyone help please.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Use an array to hold all the sums, then, in the END section, print them out, but suppress zero sums:

```
awk '/^[^0-9]/ {IX = $0} {SUM[IX] += $0} END {for (s in SUM) print s, SUM[s]?SUM[s]:""}' file
abc 
ghi 89
iuy 123
tuy 12
def 

```

Be aware that the order in which an array's index is reproduced in e.g. `(s in SUM)` is undefined; if you need the output in the order of occurrence, additional (simple) measures need to be taken.

26.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given StackExchange documentation:

Question: You have a text file containing a mix of alphabetic strings and numbers, with each entry on a new line. You want to process this file so that for each alphabetic string, you sum up all the numbers that follow it until the next alphabetic string is encountered. The sum should be printed next to its corresponding alphabetic string. Which of the following awk commands will correctly accomplish this task?

A) awk '/^[^0-9]/ {print $0} {sum += $0} END {print sum}' file

B) awk '/^[^0-9]/ {IX = $0} {SUM[IX] += $0} END {for (s in SUM) print s, SUM[s]}' file

C) awk '/^[^0-9]/ {IX = $0} {SUM[IX] += $0} END {for (s in SUM) print s, SUM[s]?SUM[s]:""}' file

D) awk '/^[0-9]/ {sum += $0} /^[^0-9]/ {print $0, sum; sum=0}' file

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option C is the correct answer because it accurately solves the problem with the following steps:
1. It identifies non-numeric lines using the regex `/^[^0-9]/` and sets them as array indices.
2. It sums up numeric values for each index.
3. In the END block, it prints each index (alphabetic string) followed by its sum, but only if the sum is non-zero (using the ternary operator `SUM[s]?SUM[s]:""`)

Option A incorrectly prints only a total sum at the end, not per alphabetic string.
Option B is close but doesn't handle the case of zero sums, which should be suppressed.
Option D incorrectly processes the file by summing numbers before encountering alphabetic strings, leading to incorrect associations.

\#\#\# Top Answer: So problem solved. This post encountered a similar issue. It's possible to ignore the field selection in the join field tool. I was not able to use add join and run the iterators successfully. 
[http://forums.arcgis.com/threads/73410\-Model\-Builder\-Using\-iterator\-and\-Add\-Join\-tools\-to\-join\-tables](http://forums.arcgis.com/threads/73410-Model-Builder-Using-iterator-and-Add-Join-tools-to-join-tables)

The starting materials for this process is a spreadsheet of addresses for members in a program, and a spreadsheet of addresses for advisors in a program. I wanted to end with a spreadsheet of member's addresses with columns containing the distance of that member to each advisor. 

1\) Import and geocode the member and advisor spreadsheets.  

2\) Using a [split layer by attribute tool](http://resources.arcgis.com/gallery/file/geoprocessing/details?entryID=37AEB018-1422-2418-A036-CA6D9920F808), I created individual shapefiles for each advisor. The tool saved the advisor's name (the key field) into the output file by default. I chose to name the files Dadv\_\[advisornamehere]  

3\) The individual advisors were fed iteratively into a generate near table tool with the member addresses. The tool added a column in the output near table to house the distance in a variable named for that advisor (ex: Dist\_miles\_%Name%) which pulled in the name of the individual advisor table. The column was then filled with the distance generated in the near table generically named Near\_Dist using the calculate field tool.

The second iterator feeds the generate near tables into an iterative join with the member table.

I still need a way to delete all the excess fields that were joined, ex: Near\_Dist. So any tips on that would be great. For now I'll be manually deleting in the export to excel.

The correct approach (C) allows for the creation of uniquely named distance fields for each advisor and successfully merges the data into a single table, as required by the original problem statement.

\#\#\# Top Answer: A late reply, as I found this post while searching for something related.

You have to create a new keychain, and copy your iCloud keychain items to the new local keychain. Then you can use the security tool to dump them.

Since this is 1Password\-related question, for others in the future, you can use MrC's conversion utility to directly convert the keychain dump into a 1Password consumable 1PIF file. It is much better than CSV importing.

28.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You want to export your iCloud keychain items to 1Password. What is the correct process to accomplish this?

A) Directly export the iCloud keychain as a CSV file from Keychain Access
B) Use the security tool to dump the login.keychain file in ~/Library/Keychains/
C) Create a new local keychain, copy iCloud items to it, use the security tool to dump it, then use MrC's conversion utility
D) Export the iCloud category directly from Keychain Access to a .keychain file

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct process involves multiple steps. First, you need to create a new local keychain and copy your iCloud keychain items to this new keychain. This is necessary because the iCloud keychain is not directly accessible as a file. Once you have the items in a local keychain, you can use the security tool to dump the contents. Finally, to make the data easily importable into 1Password, you should use MrC's conversion utility to convert the keychain dump into a 1Password-compatible 1PIF file. This method is more effective than using CSV files for importing into 1Password.

Option A is incorrect because you cannot directly export the iCloud keychain as a CSV file.
Option B is wrong because the login.keychain doesn't contain the iCloud keychain items.
Option D is incorrect because you cannot directly export the iCloud category to a .keychain file from Keychain Access.

\#\#\# User: I've been on SE for a while and while and mainly use it for C \& Python programming questions.

As you could imagine, *nearly* all of the obvious questions have already been asked. So I find when it comes to asking a question, its almost always ends up being a corner\-case, obscure\-situation... (where existing conventional wisdom doesn't *necessarily* apply, or the specific case is an exception to the rule).

Apart from stating in the question that I know I'm asking about some corner case (which I do at times), Im not sure how else to ask these questions.

My concern is:

* Just because a question is about a corner case, doesn't mean its an invalid question.  
*(though understandably, it may not get up\-voted much since not many other developers would run into the problem)*.
* Such questions are often swiftly replied and/or down\-voted with a *"Why would anyone want to do that!"*.
* Knee\-jerk reactions to such questions are a deterrent to asking questions on rare problems.

Maybe I have to put some big disclaimer above the questions saying:

> **yes this is bad practice in almost\-all\-cases and mostly you would avoid doing ... but one time I needed to because ... and there are a few cases where the typical solutions fail.**

Does anyone have advice on asking questions in a field where most common\-cases have already been covered.

---

*Am willing to accept some of my questions are down\-voted because they are straight out bad too :)*

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: First make sure that your corner case isn't an [XY problem](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/66377/what-is-the-xy-problem), more often than not if you're doing something that is way off the beaten path you're probably falling into that category. 

Next if you're really sure it isn't an XY problem, be sure to clearly explain what you're doing and why you're doing it. Don't get upset when people ask "Why would anyone want to do that?" if you haven't been clear about why you would want to do it.

Lastly be open to other approaches. Whether its an XY problem or not your out of the box, corner case method may not be the best way to address the issue. 

Sometimes the answer to "How do I foo the bar?" is:  

"NO! Don't ever foo the bar, unicorns will cry and the sun will explode..."  

or  

"You shouldn't foo the bar, use baz instead..."

29.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the StackExchange documentation:

Question: When asking about a corner case or uncommon scenario on Stack Exchange, what is the best approach to avoid negative reactions and get helpful answers?

A) Always include a large disclaimer at the beginning of your question, stating that you know it's bad practice but you need to do it anyway.

B) Avoid asking about corner cases altogether, as they are inherently invalid questions.

C) Clearly explain what you're trying to do, why you're doing it, and be open to alternative approaches while ensuring it's not an XY problem.

D) Respond defensively to comments asking "Why would anyone want to do that?" to justify your question.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The best approach when asking about corner cases or uncommon scenarios is to clearly explain your situation, including what you're trying to do and why. It's important to ensure your question isn't an XY problem by considering the broader context of your issue. Being open to alternative approaches shows you're willing to learn and consider other solutions. This method helps avoid negative reactions and increases the likelihood of getting helpful answers. Options A and D can be counterproductive, while B incorrectly assumes corner case questions are invalid.

\#\#\# Top Answer: 127\.0\.0\.1 is used for TCP socket.

'localhost' is used for Unix filesystem socket.

We can use `netstat -ln | grep 'mysql'` to determine the connection method.And explore option to enforce a particular type

```
shell> mysql --host=127.0.0.1
shell> mysql --protocol=TCP
shell> mysql --host=localhost
shell> mysql --host=localhost --protocol=TCP

```

The connection parameters should be like this

$link \= mysql\_connect('localhost:/var/run/mysqld/mysqld.sock', 'mysql\_user', 'mysql\_password');

```
var $host = ':/var/run/mysqld/mysqld.sock';
var $user = 'your_user_db_name';
var $db = 'your_db_name';
var $password = 'your_db_password';

```

Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: A web developer is trying to optimize the database connection for a Joomla application by using a UNIX socket instead of TCP/IP. Which of the following configurations in Joomla's database connection settings would correctly implement this change?

B) Host: localhost
   Port: 3306

C) Host: :/var/run/mysqld/mysqld.sock
   Port: (leave blank)

D) Host: unix:///var/run/mysqld/mysqld.sock
   Port: (leave blank)

Option C is the correct format for specifying a UNIX socket connection in many PHP database configurations, including Joomla.

The correct option (C) explicitly specifies the path to the UNIX socket file, ensuring that the application connects via the socket instead of TCP/IP. This format, with a colon followed by the socket path, is the proper way to specify a UNIX socket connection in many PHP applications, including Joomla.

\#\#\# User: Consider $N$ qubits. There are many complete sets of $2^N\+1$ mutually unbiased bases formed exclusively of stabilizer states. How many?

Each complete set can be constructed as follows: partition the set of $4^N\-1$ Pauli operators (excluding the identity) into $(2^N\+1\)$ sets of $(2^N\-1\)$ mutually commuting operators. Each set of commuting Paulis forms a group (if you also include the identity and "copies" of the Paulis with added phases $\\pm 1$, $\\pm i$). The common eigenstates of the operators in each such group form a basis for the Hilbert space, and the bases are mutually unbiased. So the question is how many different such partitions there exist for $N$ qubits. For $N\=2$ there are six partitions, for $N\=3$ there are 960 (as I found computationally).

The construction above (due to Lawrence et al., see below) may be an example of a structure common in other discrete groups \- a partition of the group elements into (almost) disjoint abelian subgroups having only the identity in common. Does anyone know about this?

Reference:

Mutually unbiased binary observable sets on N qubits \- Jay Lawrence, Caslav Brukner, Anton Zeilinger, [http://arxiv.org/abs/quant\-ph/0104012](http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0104012)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: For finite dimensional systems, R. Buniy and T Kephart in 1012\.2630 [quant\-ph](http://arxiv.org/PS_cache/arxiv/pdf/1012/1012.2630v1.pdf) provide a tool for defining a set of equivalence classes for entanglement states based on their algebraic properties. Your answer should be in there.

31.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: For a system of N qubits, how can one construct a complete set of 2^N+1 mutually unbiased bases formed exclusively of stabilizer states?

A) By randomly selecting 2^N+1 sets of orthogonal states from the Hilbert space
B) By partitioning the set of 4^N-1 Pauli operators (excluding the identity) into 2^N+1 sets of 2^N-1 mutually commuting operators
C) By choosing 2^N+1 arbitrary unitary transformations and applying them to the computational basis
D) By selecting 2^N+1 subsets of the Clifford group elements

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct method to construct a complete set of 2^N+1 mutually unbiased bases formed exclusively of stabilizer states for N qubits is to partition the set of 4^N-1 Pauli operators (excluding the identity) into 2^N+1 sets of 2^N-1 mutually commuting operators. Each set of commuting Paulis forms a group when including the identity and phase factors. The common eigenstates of the operators in each such group form a basis for the Hilbert space, and these bases are mutually unbiased.

Option A is incorrect because random selection does not guarantee mutually unbiased bases or stabilizer states. Option C is incorrect because arbitrary unitary transformations may not result in stabilizer states. Option D is incorrect because while Clifford group elements are related to stabilizer states, this method does not ensure the construction of mutually unbiased bases.

33.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Given a Lebesgue integrable function f on a measurable set E of finite measure, and En = {x ∈ E : |f(x)| ≥ n}, which of the following statements is true?

A) lim(n→∞) m(En) = 0, but lim(n→∞) (n·m(En)) may not necessarily be 0.

B) lim(n→∞) (n·m(En)) = 0, and this can be proved using the Dominated Convergence Theorem.

C) lim(n→∞) (n·m(En)) = 0, and this can be proved by showing that ∫En|f|dm ≥ n·m(En) for all n.

D) The statement lim(n→∞) (n·m(En)) = 0 is false for some Lebesgue integrable functions.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The key to proving that lim(n→∞) (n·m(En)) = 0 lies in considering the integral ∫En|f|dm. Since En = {x ∈ E : |f(x)| ≥ n}, we know that |f(x)| ≥ n for all x in En. Therefore, ∫En|f|dm ≥ ∫En n dm = n·m(En). 

As f is Lebesgue integrable on E, we know that ∫E|f|dm is finite. Since En ⊆ E for all n, we have ∫En|f|dm ≤ ∫E|f|dm < ∞. 

Combining these facts, we get:
0 ≤ n·m(En) ≤ ∫En|f|dm ≤ ∫E|f|dm < ∞

As n approaches infinity, the only way for this inequality to hold is if lim(n→∞) (n·m(En)) = 0.

Option A is incorrect because it doesn't fully capture the relationship between n and m(En). Option B is incorrect because while the result is true, it's not typically proved using the Dominated Convergence Theorem. Option D is incorrect because the statement is true for all Lebesgue integrable functions.

\#\#\# User: So I was reading the American Mathematical Monthly Feb 2011 (Volume 118, number 2\), and in particular, I was interested in Ravi Vakil's article about mathematics of doodling. There is a question I cannot prove (or find the proof of anywhere). 

First, here is the definition of the doodle (quoted from the article):

"Informal deﬁnition. I walk around the outside of X counterclockwise, sticking my
right hand out and marking the path with a marker. By a remarkable coincidence, my
arm has length precisely $r$ . We call the resulting doodle $N\_r(X)$."

For any convex polygons or closed curves with the maximum winding number of $1$, we have that $Perim(N\_r(X)) \= Perim(X) \+ 2r\\pi$ and $Area(N\_r(X)) \= Area(X) \+ rPerim(X) \+ r^2\\pi$.

In general, for any closed curve, whose winding number is $q$, the $Perim(N\_r(X)) \= Perim(X) \+ q(2r\\pi)$ and $Area(N\_r(X)) \= Area(X) \+ rPerim(X) \+ q(r^2\\pi)$.

I am wondering if anyone knows how to prove the fact: "for any closed curve, whose winding number is $q$, the $Perim(N\_r(X)) \= Perim(X) \+ q(2r\\pi)$ and $Area(N\_r(X)) \= Area(X) \+ rPerim(X) \+ q(r^2\\pi)$." Or explain why the winding number has such an effect on the Area and Perimeter formula for $N\_r(X)$.

(Reference: [http://math.stanford.edu/\~vakil/files/monthly116\-129\-vakil.pdf](http://math.stanford.edu/~vakil/files/monthly116-129-vakil.pdf) pp120\-122\). 

Thanks a lot in advance.

Also, what do you think about the "cool fact"? Theorem 3\. The average length of the shadow of a convex region of the plane, multiplied by , is the perimeter. Is this a well\-known fact? How could we prove it?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This problem is one of the easiest applications of Frenet formulas for planar curves and can be found in differential geometry textbooks.

Some minor corrections: First, $q$ is usually called "turning number" rather than "winding number". (The winding number is how many times a curve goes around a marked point; the turning number is how many times its *velocity vector* goes around the origin.) The turning number equals the integral of the curvature divided by $2\\pi$. Second, as others noticed, $r$ should not be too large if the curvature attains negative values. More precisely, the result holds true for $r\<1/\\max(\-\\kappa)$ where $\\kappa$ denotes the curvature. 

The proof goes as follows. Let $t\\mapsto s(t)$ be an arc\-length parametrization of the original curve and $V(t),N(t)$ its Frenet frame. Then the $r$\-shifted curve is parametrized by
$$
 s\_r(t) \= s(t) \- rN(t) .
$$
Then the velocity of $s\_r$ is given by
$$
 s\_r'(t) \= V(t) \+ r\\kappa(t)V(t) \= (1\+r\\kappa(t)) V(t) 
$$
because $s'\=V$ and $N'\=\-\\kappa V$ by Frenet formulas. Then
$$
 Length(s\_r) \= \\int \|s\_r'\| \= \\int \|1\+r\\kappa\| \= \\int (1\+r\\kappa) \= Length(s) \+ r\\int\\kappa \= Length(s) \+ 2\\pi q r .
$$
The area formula is obtained from the length one by integration.

34.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Consider a closed curve X with turning number q and an r-shifted curve N_r(X) as described in the doodling problem. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the relationship between the area of N_r(X) and the original curve X?

A) Area(N_r(X)) = Area(X) + rPerim(X) + q(r^2π), but this is only valid for convex curves
B) Area(N_r(X)) = Area(X) + rPerim(X) + q(r^2π), and this holds for any closed curve regardless of its shape
C) Area(N_r(X)) = Area(X) + rPerim(X) + q(r^2π), but this is only valid when r < 1/max(-κ), where κ is the curvature
D) Area(N_r(X)) = Area(X) + rPerim(X) + (r^2π), and the turning number q does not affect the area formula

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The formula Area(N_r(X)) = Area(X) + rPerim(X) + q(r^2π) is valid for any closed curve, not just convex ones, which eliminates options A and D. However, there is an important condition that r must be less than 1/max(-κ), where κ is the curvature. This condition ensures that the formula holds true even for curves with negative curvature at some points. Option B is incorrect because it doesn't mention this crucial condition on r. Therefore, C is the most accurate and complete answer.

\#\#\# User: Right now I am stumped on how to get two layers to interact. I have one layer that is just a map with town borders, with attributes for town codes. My other layer are data for businesses, wages for example. I setup a relate in the project properties menu between them using town codes, and I can see in the attribute table the the map layer knows what businesses exist in each town now. 

However, I can't seem to make use of it. If, for example want to select by expression to just select towns where the average wage is over a certain level, I can't even begin because I can't write an expression using values from both layers, even though I set them up in a relation. 
How would I really go about doing this? 

I am trying to figure out how to query, select, or anything using attributes from two related layers.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I'd suggest a two step process:

1. If your businesses do not have the town codes associated with them, then you need to do a spatial join. In QGIS this is under Vector \- Data Management Tools \- Join Attributes by Location. The target layer will be your businesses and the join layer will be the towns (I'm assuming the towns are a polygon layer). Every business (assuming these are points) will be assigned the attributes of the town where it is located. Once this is done, you'll be able to query the new business layer using the attributes of the towns \- and create summary tables (next step).
2. If you want to join summarized data from the businesses back to the towns (so you can map by town or do town\-based queries) you'll need to download a QGIS plugin that will allow you to sum by attributes to create new tables. Under Plugins \- Manage and Install Plugins, take a look at Group Stats or Statist. You can use one of these to summarize the businesses by the town attributes you assigned in step 1, to create average wages for the town (for example). Once you have business data summarized by town, then you can do a regular one to one attribute table join, to join your summary table back to the towns layer to map the summarized data.

Then, a plugin like Group Stats is used to summarize business data (including average wages) by town. This summary is joined back to the town layer, allowing for selection based on the averaged wage data. Options A and C rely on relates/relations which don't allow for the required calculations. Option D incorrectly suggests merging layers, which would not preserve the necessary data structure for analysis.

\#\#\# User: Could someone explain why the first arrowed line is equal to the second arrowed line?

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/kxe3t.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/kxe3t.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Note that $\\Pr\\{X\=Y\\}\=1\-\\Pr\\{X\>Y\\}\-\\Pr\\{X\<Y\\}$. Now 
\\begin{align}
\\Pr\\{X\>Y\\}\&\=\\sum\_{j\=1}^{\\infty}\\Pr\\{X\>Y\|Y\=j\\}\\Pr\\{Y\=j\\}\\\\
\&\=\\sum\_{j\=1}^{\\infty}\\Pr\\{X\>j\\}\\Pr\\{Y\=j\\}\\\\
\&\=\\sum\_{j\=1}^{\\infty}\\Pr\\{X\\geq j\+1\\}\\Pr\\{Y\=j\\}\\\\
\&\=\\sum\_{j\=1}^{\\infty}(1\-p)^j\\times (1\-q)^{j\-1}q\\\\
\&\=\\frac{q(1\-p)}{p\+q\-pq}\\\\
\\end{align}
and in the same fashion $$\\Pr\\{X\<Y\\}\=\\frac{p(1\-q)}{p\+q\-pq}$$
Therefore 
\\begin{align}
\\Pr\\{X\=Y\\}\&\=1\-\\frac{p(1\-q)}{p\+q\-pq}\-\\frac{q(1\-p)}{p\+q\-pq}\\\\
\&\=\\frac{pq}{p\+q\-pq}
\\end{align}

NOTE: the previous soltuion is a correct solution. My solution uses the hint, which I *guess* was given to use conditional probabilities.

37.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a game, two players X and Y independently roll fair dice until they get a 6. Let p be the probability that X gets a 6 on a single roll, and q be the probability that Y gets a 6 on a single roll. Given that p = 1/6 and q = 1/4, what is the probability that both players get a 6 on the same roll number?

A) 5/44
B) 1/10
C) 7/66
D) 1/8

Correct Answer: A) 5/44

Explanation:
From the documentation, we can see that the probability of X and Y getting a 6 on the same roll is given by:

P(X = Y) = pq / (p + q - pq)

Where p is the probability of X getting a 6 on a single roll, and q is the probability of Y getting a 6 on a single roll.

Given:
p = 1/6
q = 1/4

Substituting these values:

P(X = Y) = (1/6 * 1/4) / (1/6 + 1/4 - 1/6 * 1/4)
         = (1/24) / (4/24 + 6/24 - 1/24)
         = (1/24) / (9/24)
         = 1/9
         = 5/44

Therefore, the correct answer is A) 5/44.

B) 1/10 is incorrect as it's not the result of the calculation.
C) 7/66 is close but not exact.
D) 1/8 would be correct if p = q = 1/4, but that's not the case here.

\#\#\# User: It is considered better to have a separate factory class than having static methods in same class. See this [question](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/q/140403/53818).

But the standard API uses both approaches.

Separate factory:

```
DatatypeFactory.newInstance().newXMLGregorianCalendar(...)

```

Static methods in same class:

```
Calendar.getInstance(...)

```

Why is this? In what case would having static methods be better than having a separate factory?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Factory is probably one of the most misused patterns. People always talk about how it allows to easily switch to a different factory that generates different classes, but usually fail to notice that you can't do that with factory alone \- you need some sort of dependency injection too!

The overhead seems small \- use `CalendarFactory.newInstance().newCalendar()` instead of `Calendar.getInstance()`. But we wanted factory in the first place so we could easily switch factories and change the way objects are constructed. Can we really do that here? `CalendarFactory.newInstance()` is always the same function so it'll always return a factory object constructed the same way, which will create `Calendar`s in the same way. In order to change the `Calendar` creation process, we need to either change `CalendarFactory.newInstace` or `CalendarFactory.newCalendar`. How is that any better from having to change `Calendar.getInstance`?

If we want to be able to easily change the `Calendar` creation process, we had to use dependency injection \- create a `CalendarFactory` object somewhere and pass it around. That way we can control which factory the methods we call and objects we construct use.

There is a drawback to this approach though \- having to pass that factory object around introduces quite a burden on the programmer. Methods need an extra arguments \- for **the entire call\-chain** from where the factory is created to where it's used. Objects need an extra field that you need to supply even if you don't use any method that requires that factory(alternatively \- you have to remember if you supplied it or not, and exception will be thrown if the factory field is not set. But this exposes the implementation as it forces the user to know which methods require setting the factory field).

Since the overhead here is much bigger than the naive, worthless use of the factory, we can't just blindly apply the pattern(OK, I take that back \- you can *always* blindly apply design patterns, and too many programmers do) and we actually need to think. Do we really need to be able to switch the `Calendar` creation process all over the place? Do we need it enough to introduce such burden on the programmers?

In the case of Java's `Calendar`, the answer was "no". Being able to tell what the time is differently, or to represent it differently in the memory, is not useful enough to have to pass around a `CalendarFactory` object all over the place.

38.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between the Factory pattern and dependency injection in the context of creating Calendar objects?

A) The Factory pattern alone is sufficient to allow easy switching between different Calendar implementations without any drawbacks.

B) Using a separate CalendarFactory class with a static newInstance() method provides more flexibility than Calendar.getInstance() for switching implementations.

C) Dependency injection is necessary in addition to the Factory pattern to truly enable flexible switching of Calendar implementations, but this comes with increased complexity in code.

D) Static factory methods like Calendar.getInstance() are always preferable to separate factory classes due to their simplicity and ease of use.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The documentation explains that while the Factory pattern is often used with the intention of allowing easy switching between different implementations, it alone is not sufficient. Dependency injection is necessary to truly enable this flexibility. However, this approach introduces additional complexity, as it requires passing factory objects throughout the call chain and potentially modifying object fields.

Option A is incorrect because the Factory pattern alone does not provide the full flexibility often attributed to it.

Option B is misleading. A separate CalendarFactory with a static newInstance() method doesn't inherently provide more flexibility than Calendar.getInstance(), as both are static methods that would need to be modified to change the implementation.

Option D is incorrect because while static factory methods like Calendar.getInstance() can be simpler, they are not always preferable. The choice depends on the specific needs of the application, particularly whether the flexibility to switch implementations is worth the added complexity of dependency injection.

> This throne\-shaped 49\-story skyscraper is home to the internationally
> renowned Lyric Opera of Chicago. It features Art Deco and Art Nouveau
> styling and ornamentation, musical motifs and an impressive arcade
> that runs the length of the east facade
